page.title: 02Farming types and areas
page.content: {Adbaston} The hilly North West area is predominantly rough pasture, whilst the loams and clay loams of the West, South and Central areas contain arable crops and more intensively managed grass for silage. One farm was entirely arable, growing wheat, barley and sugar beet, the others being either mixed or live- stock only. Arable crops on mixed farms were wheat, barley and oilseed rape. Cattle on mixed farms were mostly for beef, one farm at Bishops Offley having 250 beef animals. In the livestock only group, cattle for milk and beef were in equal numbers. Other livestock included sheep on 3 farms and there was a 300 strong pig unit at 'The Tunstalls'. Farm sizes (ha) vary from 7 to 98, with a mean of 42 ha. The mean for arable and mixed is 61 ha, others 23ha.
